intro: Colutea insularis, commonly known as the island corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters. The plant produces small, pink or purple flowers in clusters, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are trifoliate, consisting of three leaflets that are lance-shaped and slightly hairy. Colutea insularis is often found in rocky or sandy soils, thriving in well-drained environments.
